reading_mnemonic:
This uses the kun'yomi reading of 毎, which you haven't learned yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

<vocabulary>For every</vocabulary> kanji you burn, you <reading>go to</reading> (ごと) Tokyo Disneyland as a reward. It's a bit of an expensive habit, but I think you deserve it.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. いち goes to いっ.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The 下 uses the alternative reading of げ but 巻 is all good and normal.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned the on'yomi for 狼 (wolf) yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember that, as well as which on'yomi to use for 人:

There's a <vocabulary>werewolf</vocabulary> in front of you wearing  <reading>jean</reading>s and eating <reading>roe</reading> (じんろう). This is typical behavior for werewolves, as I'm sure you know.

You might be tempted to read this with on’yomi, but this is actually 今 and 更に put together, just without the に particle at the end. Try to remember it in this way, or just make a mental note to use kun’yomi here!

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. It's exactly the same as the reading for 関わる, so here's a reminder of that mnemonic to help you:

Remember the "<reading>Kaw Kaw</reading> (かか) Crow Gang"? They are bad news, always eating from garbage and squawking "kaw kaw"... You don't want <vocabulary>to be involved</vocabulary> with them.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Remember how 今すぐ means "at once"? Well that's the key <vocabulary>to surpass</vocabulary>ing others. You have to do everything 今<reading>すぐ</reading>!!!

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well, but just remember that the second kanji is read as ぱい because of the rendaku on はい.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading is shared with 割る.

The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji. き from ひき kind of just gets stuffed into the 引 and hidden away like that strange collection of fingernails you have hidden in your closet drawer inside of a 35mm film container. Also remember that the reading gets changed to びき here because of that pesky rendaku.
What is particularly effective? It's your <reading>key</reading> (き). It's effective at opening your house door.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with 収まる, but here's a mnemonic to remind you just in case:

You need <vocabulary>to store</vocabulary> all of the <reading>o</reading>ld <reading>saw</reading>s (おさ). You were able <vocabulary>to finish</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to achieve</vocabulary> everything you wanted with them, so it's time to put them away so they'll be safe.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 刺 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

After doing business in Japan, you'll have so many <vocabulary>business card</vocabulary>s you can count them like <reading>shee</reading>p (し) when you're trying to get to sleep. One business card, two business cards… See them leaping over the sheep fence as you begin to nod off.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

They don't want <vocabulary>to include</vocabulary> you in their game? Well, "<reading>F***</reading> (ふく) you!" you yell at them, because they wouldn't include you.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading is shared with 呼ぶ, so remember that and you'll be able to read this too.

Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember this reading:

It's okay <vocabulary>to question something</vocabulary>, but you should be careful not to step on someone else's <reading>toe</reading>s (と) by doing so. Questioning certain things can offend people, especially when they have strong feelings about it! So be careful about those toes.
Although this is a single kanji all alone, it uses the on'yomi reading. This is the reading you learned with the kanji, you lucky duck.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you:

What <vocabulary>increase</vocabulary>s with time? Your love for your <reading>ma</reading>ma (ま)! Your love for her will grow and grow the older you get! I love you, mama!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Do you know the word いる? This is the kanji version! If you've been studying Japanese up to this point you probably already know that word. You can associate these two things together into one and remember the reading at the same time!

When 城 is added to a place name like this, it takes the on'yomi. You haven't learned this yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

The lord of <vocabulary>Okayama Castle</vocabulary> is none other than <reading>Joe</reading> (じょう), your local farmhand friend. How a farmhand like Joe managed to become the lord of a Japanese castle is beyond even us, but it's Lord Joe to you now.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The thing you are rolling up is your <reading>ma</reading> (ま). She's going wild again, so you throw her into a blanket and roll her up to hold her down.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The はい goes to a ぱい, because… elderly persons love <reading>pie</reading> (ぱい), right?
The reading is shared with 建てる, so if you know 建てる then you should be able to read this word as well.
Just imagine the <vocabulary>shadow</vocabulary> of a <reading>cage</reading> (かげ). Lots of long bars. Looks good.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for 後 is the long こう reading, though. Just think of your junior being <reading>こう</reading>いち.
What have you <vocabulary>become accustomed to</vocabulary>? All the <reading>Na</reading>rwhals (な) you hang out with. They take some getting used to.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. You may have to think back to some other words using 投 to remember the on'yomi reading, 投資 for example.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Just go ahead and extract it out of your memory so you can use it here.
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

The reading is つか, so to remember that with <vocabulary>to be caught</vocabulary>, think about how you're a police officer chasing some criminals. Unfortunately, they split up into <reading>two ca</reading>rs (つか), meaning they can't both be caught. Guess you should have called for backup...

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're searching all around for a "<reading>sagger</reading>" (さが) on your body. This is a flap of skin that is sagging on your body really far, and you probably should get it removed.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

This is the kun'yomi reading for 掛 and the on'yomi for 算. And the さん reading is rendaku'd into ざん. This is the same for all the math-ish words (addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division), so try to remember that, because you'll see it again!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

You haven't learned either of these readings yet. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember them:

You're admiring the <vocabulary>scenery</vocabulary> and you notice key marks all over everything. You realize it's that girl who keys everything and you say to yourself <reading>kay she key</reading>ed (けしき) that, <reading>kay she key</reading>ed (けしき) this.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Do you care a lot about grammar? I don't care, unless it has to do with <reading>comma</reading>s (かま). Then I do flip out.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since you didn't learn the on'yomi for 様 with the kanji, here's a mnemonic to help you out. You see a pattern in your <reading>yo</reading>gurt (よう). The yogurt is an imitation of life. So deep, man. So deep.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

The reading is the kun'yomi reading, but that's the reading you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this one too. If you need a refresher, here's a mnemonic to help you:

Looking for a place that's <vocabulary>cool</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>refreshing</vocabulary>? Go to the <reading>Sue Zoo</reading> (すず). Imagine swimming with Sue the penguin in the refreshing water of her pool. Feels good!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just remember that the reading for 足 in this one is ぞく because of that pesky rendaku.
The reading is the same as 準備.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Do you remember learning 現れる? This has the same exact pronunciation!

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You learned the readings for both of these, but 役 uses a less common reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember this:

You're <vocabulary>actively working</vocabulary> at the <reading>駅</reading> (えき) and you plan to remain <vocabulary>active</vocabulary> there forever! You sure do love that 駅, it's like you're inseparable.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

The reading for this is a bit of a weird one. It uses on'yomi for 素, then it uses the kun'yomi for 直. You know both readings, but it's all a little strange, so here's a mnemonic help you:

To present yourself as an <vocabulary>honest</vocabulary> person, you should hurry up and change into a <reading>su</reading>it <reading>now</reading> (すなお). We all know that people in suits look more honest and upfront, so go get suited up now!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The けつ shortens to けっ.

The thing that is threatening <vocabulary>to strangle</vocabulary> you is actually a <reading>shee</reading>p (し)! The sheep comes to your house and says, "here's the sheep mail!" and then tries to strangle you. It puts its hard feet on your neck though it's pretty ineffective.
Your friend wants <vocabulary>to wring out</vocabulary> a towel, but before she does so <reading>she bow</reading>s (しぼ) to the towel to show her respect for it.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Be careful though, 絶 is normally read as ぜつ, but in this case it is shortened to ぜっ.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
You already know the reading of 肩, and this is just that with some hiragana added on!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

What are clothes, really? Some people say <vocabulary>clothes</vocabulary> are the <reading>chromo</reading>somes (ころも) of your personal style — each garment carries information about your unique identity. Other people say clothes are simply the <reading>key</reading> to not being <reading>nu</reading>de (きぬ). What do you think?

Both ころも and きぬ mean "clothes," but these usages are old-fashioned. Also note that the more modern meaning of "coating" or "breading" uses only the ころも reading!

<reading>Oh, gee, now</reading> (おぎな) you're going <vocabulary>to supplement</vocabulary> it? That would have been helpful earlier. Might help to say "oh gee now" with a ぎ sound instead of "ji" sound out loud, too. This is a tricky reading, won't be learned too easily, so think about it a bit now.
The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.
This is a combination of the words 規則 and 正しい, which you learned already, so you should be able to read this word too.
<reading>YOU TA</reading>KE (うった) MY THINGS, I AM GOING <vocabulary>TO SUE</vocabulary> YOU!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You discovered <vocabulary>plentiful</vocabulary> <reading>yu</reading>rt <reading>ta</reading>cos (ゆた) inside the yurt you’re staying in. Picture yourself savoring the richly flavored yurt tacos beside your yurt while being immersed in the abundant nature around you.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The readings are 長 from 長い, normal 崎 and normal 県.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This word uses the kun'yomi reading, which you already learned. Go you!

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: <vocabulary>to limit</vocabulary> things, you have something called a <reading>ca</reading>r (か) <reading>guillotine</reading> (ぎ) which you drive around limiting everything with.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Hide your <reading>cock</reading> (かく)! You have a ton of roosters but you don't want people to know about them, so you gotta hide your cocks. What did you think I was talking about?
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading is the same as the vocab word 革, because this word is like two separate words put together (so it's treated as single words too, giving it that reading).

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Of course it will help to know 革命 already as well.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: <reading>He be</reading> (ひび) echoing... <reading>He be</reading> (ひび) echoing... <reading>He be</reading> (ひび) echoing... <reading>He be</reading> (ひび) echoing... <reading>He be</reading> (ひび) echoing...

This word gets its reading from the kanji 頑 and the verb 張る put together, but the 張る part gets rendaku'd to ばる. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember that rendaku:

When you have <vocabulary>to persevere</vocabulary>, you always scream <reading>baa</reading> (ば)! Not sure why, you just think when someone has <vocabulary>to do one's best</vocabulary>, screaming "baa!" is a great motivator. Kinda like how weightlifters and tennis players grunt when they're doing their best, you know? Baa!

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: This <vocabulary>vivid</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>splendid</vocabulary> fresh fish is MINE! You grab the <reading>other</reading> (あざ) one that's not as vivid and splendid. This one is mine.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
